rev.diff:
Line 62: Line 62:
The diversity of Linux distributions is due to technical, organizational, and philosophical variation among vendors and users. The permissive licensing of free software means that any user with sufficient knowledge and interest can customize an existing distribution or design to suit his or her own needs.
The diversity of Linux distributions is due to technical, organizational, and philosophical variation among vendors and users. The permissive licensing of free software means that any user with sufficient knowledge and interest can customize an existing distribution or design to suit his or her own needs.
â
===Installation-free distributions (LiveCDs)===
+
===Installation-free distributions (Live CDs)===
â
{{main|LiveCD|Live USB}}
+
{{main|Live CD|Live USB}}
â
A LiveDistro or LiveCD, is a Linux distribution that can be booted from a [[compact disc]] or other medium (such as a [[DVD]] or [[USB flash drive]]) instead of the conventional [[hard drive]]. Some minimal distributions such as [[tomsrtbt]] can be run directly from as little as one floppy disk without needing to change the hard drive contents.
+
A LiveDistro or Live CD, is a Linux distribution that can be booted from a [[compact disc]] or other medium (such as a [[DVD]] or [[USB flash drive]]) instead of the conventional [[hard drive]]. Some minimal distributions such as [[tomsrtbt]] can be run directly from as little as one floppy disk without needing to change the hard drive contents.
The read-only nature of CDs and DVDs means that user data cannot be stored with the operating system, but must be written to some other device (such as a USB flash drive or an installed hard drive) if any is to be kept. Temporary operating system data is usually kept solely in [[random access memory|RAM]].
The read-only nature of CDs and DVDs means that user data cannot be stored with the operating system, but must be written to some other device (such as a USB flash drive or an installed hard drive) if any is to be kept. Temporary operating system data is usually kept solely in [[random access memory|RAM]].
â
The portablility is advantageous for applications such as demonstrations, borrowing someone else's computer, rescue operations, and as installation media for a standard distribution. Many popular distributions come in both "Live" and conventional forms (the conventional form being a network or removable media image which is intended to be used for installation only). This includes [[SUSE]], [[Ubuntu (operating system)|Ubuntu]], [[Mepis]], and [[Fedora (Linux distribution)|Fedora]]. Some distributions, such as [[Knoppix]] and [[Dyne:bolic]], are designed primarily for LiveCD or LiveDVD use.
+
The portablility is advantageous for applications such as demonstrations, borrowing someone else's computer, rescue operations, and as installation media for a standard distribution. Many popular distributions come in both "Live" and conventional forms (the conventional form being a network or removable media image which is intended to be used for installation only). This includes [[SUSE]], [[Ubuntu (operating system)|Ubuntu]], [[Mepis]], and [[Fedora (Linux distribution)|Fedora]]. Some distributions, such as [[Knoppix]] and [[Dyne:bolic]], are designed primarily for Live CD or Live DVD use.

Line 80: Line 80:
* [[Fedora (Linux distribution)|Fedora]] which is a community distribution sponsored by [[Red Hat]]
* [[Fedora (Linux distribution)|Fedora]] which is a community distribution sponsored by [[Red Hat]]
* [[Gentoo Linux|Gentoo]], a distribution targeted at [[power user]]s, known for its [[FreeBSD Ports]]-like automated system for compiling applications from source code
* [[Gentoo Linux|Gentoo]], a distribution targeted at [[power user]]s, known for its [[FreeBSD Ports]]-like automated system for compiling applications from source code
â
* [[Knoppix]], a [[LiveCD]] distribution that runs completely from [[removable media]] and without installation to a hard disk
+
* [[Knoppix]], a [[Live CD]] distribution that runs completely from [[removable media]] and without installation to a hard disk
* [[Linspire]], a commercial desktop distribution based on Ubuntu (and thus Debian), and once the defendant in the [[Microsoft vs. Lindows]] lawsuit over its former name.
* [[Linspire]], a commercial desktop distribution based on Ubuntu (and thus Debian), and once the defendant in the [[Microsoft vs. Lindows]] lawsuit over its former name.
* [[Mandriva Linux|Mandriva]], a Red Hat derivative popular in France and Brazil, today maintained by the French company of the same name
* [[Mandriva Linux|Mandriva]], a Red Hat derivative popular in France and Brazil, today maintained by the French company of the same name
Line 107: Line 107:
There are tools available to help making the decision, such as several different versions of the Linux Distribution Chooser<ref>[http://www.zegeniestudios.net/ldc/ zegenie Studios Linux Distribution Chooser<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>[http://www.tuxs.org/chooser/ (:^tuxs.org) Linux Distribution Chooser<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>[http://desktoplinuxathome.com/distro.html Desktop Linux At Home - Distro Selector<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> and the universal package search tool, whohas.<ref>[http://www.philippwesche.org/2004/programs/whohas/intro.html Philipp's Homepage: whohas<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> There are some easy ways to try out several Linux distributions before deciding on one. [[Multi Distro]] is a [[Live CD]] that contains nine space-saving distributions.<ref>[http://www.linux.com/article.pl?sid=06/05/22/1353239 Linux.com :: Multi Distro is Linux times 9 on a single CD-R<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Tools are available to make such CDs and DVDs, among them Nautopia.<ref>[http://applications.linux.com/article.pl?sid=06/03/16/1724219&tid=47 Linux.com :: Multiple live CDs in one DVD<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
There are tools available to help making the decision, such as several different versions of the Linux Distribution Chooser<ref>[http://www.zegeniestudios.net/ldc/ zegenie Studios Linux Distribution Chooser<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>[http://www.tuxs.org/chooser/ (:^tuxs.org) Linux Distribution Chooser<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>[http://desktoplinuxathome.com/distro.html Desktop Linux At Home - Distro Selector<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> and the universal package search tool, whohas.<ref>[http://www.philippwesche.org/2004/programs/whohas/intro.html Philipp's Homepage: whohas<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> There are some easy ways to try out several Linux distributions before deciding on one. [[Multi Distro]] is a [[Live CD]] that contains nine space-saving distributions.<ref>[http://www.linux.com/article.pl?sid=06/05/22/1353239 Linux.com :: Multi Distro is Linux times 9 on a single CD-R<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Tools are available to make such CDs and DVDs, among them Nautopia.<ref>[http://applications.linux.com/article.pl?sid=06/03/16/1724219&tid=47 Linux.com :: Multiple live CDs in one DVD<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
â
Virtual machines such as [[QEMU]], [[VirtualBox]] and [[VMware]] permit booting of LiveCD image files without actually burning a CD.
+
Virtual machines such as [[QEMU]], [[VirtualBox]] and [[VMware]] permit booting of Live CD image files without actually burning a CD.
â
Details and interest rankings of Linux distributions are available on [[DistroWatch]] and a fairly comprehensive list of Live CDs is [http://www.livecdlist.com/ The LiveCD List]. Some websites such as [http://shots.osdir.com/ OSDir.com] and [http://www.osvids.com/ OSVids.com] offer screenshots and videos as a means to getting a first impression of various distributions.
+
Details and interest rankings of Linux distributions are available on [[DistroWatch]] and a fairly comprehensive list of Live CDs is [http://www.livecdlist.com/ The Live CD List]. Some websites such as [http://shots.osdir.com/ OSDir.com] and [http://www.osvids.com/ OSVids.com] offer screenshots and videos as a means to getting a first impression of various distributions.
[[Workspot]] provides online Linux desktop demos using [[Virtual Network Computing]] (VNC).
[[Workspot]] provides online Linux desktop demos using [[Virtual Network Computing]] (VNC).
